intro: Microsechium gonzalo-palomae, commonly known as the Gonzalo-Palomá's spiderwort, is a flowering plant native to the cloud forests of Ecuador. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its small, delicate flowers that typically bloom in shades of white and purple. The plant has lance-shaped leaves and produces a unique inflorescence that resembles a cluster of tiny bells. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found growing on rocky substrates in montane regions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
